U.S. Oil & Refining Co.

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

Introduction
U. S. Oil & Refining Co. is an independent petroleum refiner located on 136 acres in the Port of Tacoma with the facilities and personnel to process approximately 40000 barrels per day of crude oil into products.  The facilities include over 2 million barrels of storage capacity for crude oil feedstocks, intermediates, and finished products.  The hydrocarbon materials range from volatiles such as liquid butane and gasolines, through distillates such as turbine aviation fuels, diesel and catalytic cracker feedstock, to heavy residuals and byproducts such as fuel oils, asphalt products and liquid sulfur respectively.  The refinery has operated in this location since 1957 and has evolved with the industry into a complex, yet safe, clean, and efficient facility with 160 employees.

The refinery, which consists of a crude oil processing area, tank farm, finished product loading racks, and office area, is bounded by Marshall Avenue to the South, Lincoln Avenue to the Northwest and Port of Tacoma land to the East, West, and North.  The refinery's main processing units consist of a crude oil unit, two catalytic reformers, one diesel hydrotreater unit, sulfur processing facilities, and ancillary utilities.  The substances handled at the refinery that are regulated by 40 CFR Part 68 include Propane, Butane, Isobutane, Pentane, and Isopentane.

It is our policy to follow responsible safety, environmental, and quality practices to ensure continuous improvements in protecting our employees, the public, and the environment.  Additionally, our training programs ensure employees are aware of their responsibilities and understand the necessity of operating all processes in continuous compliance with all applicable safety and environmental regulations as well as stringent company standards.

Prevention Program
The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at U.S. Oil & Refin

ing Co.  The program is based on the elements of Process Safety Management (OSHA) and Accidental Release Prevention Programs (EPA).  Each of the 12 elements is fully implemented and integrated into the standard operating practices of the refinery.  Summarized below are brief descriptions of each of the elements:

Employee Participation

U.S. Oil & Refining Co. actively encourages employees to participate in all phases of process safety management and chemical accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation at the refinery range from updating technical documents and chemical information, to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.

Process Safety Information

Critical information on properties of feedstocks, intermediates, and finished products is made readily available to facility personnel through Material Safety Data Sheets, current drawings, and comprehensive operations manuals.

The refinery maintains various technical documentation that provide key information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, as well as design pressure, temperature, and electrical ratings.  This information, along with written procedures carried out by trained personnel, provides the basis for establishing excellent inspection and maintenance systems.  These systems enable U.S. Oil & Refining Co. to evaluate proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis

U. S. Oil & Refining Co. has a comprehensive program in place to ensure that hazards associated with the operations on site are identified and minimized.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measu

res when the team believes such measures are necessary. 

Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained. 

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, U.S. Oil & Refining Co. periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and the results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.  Team findings are forwarded to management for consideration and the final resolutions of the findings are documented and retained.

Operating Procedures

Clear and concise instructions have been developed by teams of experienced personnel for all facility operations.  The procedures are kept current by frequent, regularly scheduled review, and by integrating the Management of Change procedures.  The operating procedures address various modes of process operation, such as (1) Unit Startup, (2) Normal Operations, (3) Temporary Operations, (4) Planned or Emergency Shutdown, and (5) Initial Process Startup.

Additionally, U.S. Oil & Refining Co. maintains comprehensive operating manuals that provide guidance on all facets of the operation, including specific responses if process or equipment parameters are out of optimal operating ranges.

Training 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, U.S. Oil & Refining Co. has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in refinery operations if they are not already familia

r with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) they are allowed to work independently. 

In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years.  All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training. 

Contractors 

U.S. Oil & Refining Co. uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the refinery has a comprehensive pre-qualification procedure in place.  During the pre-qualification process, U.S. Oil & Refining Co. evaluates contractor safety programs and performance prior to selecting the contractor to perform work at the refinery.  Once a contractor is approved to provide service at the refinery, their performance is monitored to ensure that contractors are meeting our expectation that all work is carried out safely.

U.S. Oil & Refining Co. provides contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work at the refinery.  These activities help to ensure that contractors are able to perform their work in a safe manner, are aware of the hazards in their workplace, and understand and follow all site safety rules.

 Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) 

U.S. Oil & Refining Co. conducts a PSSR for any new process equipment or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety

information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that procedures, personnel, and the new or modified equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. 

The PSSR review provides the final check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. 

Mechanical Integrity 

U.S. Oil & Refining Co. has well established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems; controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) maintaining written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner.  Written procedures help to ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessel).  If a deficiency is identified, maintenance personnel will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or an MOC team will

review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment. 

Safe Work Practices 

U.S. Oil & Refining Co. has a comprehensive work practices system in place that utilizes a permit system for all maintenance activities at the refinery.  Before any work can be performed on any equipment in the refinery, a Safe Work Permit must be obtained from the operations personnel in charge of the process area affected by the work.  The Safe Work Permit is used to determine what procedures and additional permits will be required to safely perform each job.

Examples of workplace practices that may be employed include: (1) control of the entry/presence of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change 

U .S. Oil & Refining Co. has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process-operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel

are provided any necessary training on the change. 

Incident Investigation 

U.S. Oil & Refining Co. promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to refinery management for resolution. 

Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHA?s and PHA revalidations.

 Compliance Audits 

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, U.S. Oil & Refining Co. periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the most recent audit reports are retained. 

CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 

In addition to the general accident prevention program activities listed above, U.S. Oil & Refining Co. has safety features on many units to help quickly detect, contain or control, and reduce the consequences of (mitigate) an accidental release.  The following types of safety features are used in various proces

ses: 

Release Detection 

1. Gas detectors with alarms. 
2. Control room operators continuously monitoring critical process parameters.
3. Outside operators continuously monitoring operations. 

Release Containment/Control 

1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and combust episodic releases. 
2. Valves to permit Isolation of the process (manual or automated). 
3. Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature). 
4. Curbing and diking to contain liquid releases. 
5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g. uninterruptible power supply for process controls and utilities; backup firewater pump). 
6. Atmospheric relief devices. 

Release Mitigation 

1. Deluge system for specific equipment. 
2. Trained emergency response personnel. 
3. Personal protective equipment (e.g.. protective clothing; self-contained breathing apparatus). 

 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

U.S. Oil & Refining Co. maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address emergency response, including evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.

Additionally, U.S. Oil & Refining Co. has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the proper use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to refinery processes or other refinery facilities.  The emergency response program changes are administered through the MO

C process, which includes information and/or training affected personnel with regard to the changes made.

The emergency response plan at the refinery is coordinated with the Pierce County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes communications as necessary with local emergency response officials, local government officials, and local industry representatives.  U.S. Oil & Refining Co. has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Tacoma Fire Department).  This provides a means of notifying the public if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. 

In the event of an accidental release at the refinery, the shift supervisor would determine if the plant emergency is of a nature that outside assistance is required.  The first outside assistance called is the Tacoma City Fire Department for fire, injury or large vapor or liquid release.  The refinery emergency whistle would be activated and plant personnel evacuated upwind of the release.  The shift supervisor is the initial on-site incident commander.  In the event of a release that could impact areas outside of the refinery, the Tacoma Fire Department is responsible for notification of the neighboring community.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

We believe that continuous improvement is the best way to be successful in the future.  This is especially true in the safety, health and environmental areas.  Our philosophy is to continuously look for opportunities to improve our abilities in protecting our people and our community.  U.S. Oil & Refining Co. uses findings from PHAs, incident investigations, and employee safety meetings as a means of continuously improving our safety performance.
